item.description:
From our member who suggested this, Billie Gregorio: "Let's let them play, run, and chase and get some exercise.  A happy dog is a tired one!!  This is our second meet-up together.  The dogs seem to enjoy a few toys, sticks and tug-a-war rope play.  It's a large, safe environment to work on dog socialization, some dog training, and companionship of other bully owners.  If you're interested in having some fun and exercise for your furry pet, come meet us and say hi!!!"

NEBBC Dog/Handler Etiquette - PLEASE REVIEW:
~ Avoid head-on greetings between dogs.
~ Until you are familiar with individual dogs AND handlers, contact between dogs must be kept to a minimum.
~ Prevent your dog from lunging on leash, whether it is in play or not.
~ Dog(s) must be kept under owner control at all times.
~ Do not allow your dog to surprise, or "sneak up on" other dogs.
~ A VERY important note: Just because two dogs are friendly, does not necessarily mean they are going to be friendly with each other. Make no assumptions and DO NOT LET YOUR DOG GREET ANOTHER DOG until you have asked and BEEN GIVEN PERMISSION by the owner.

From the president & founder of the New England Bully Breed Club: "This meetup is being repeated on a trial basis for the month of March.  Dog parks are controversial topics among both bully breed lovers, and their detractors.  All town by-laws are always expected to be followed at these events, including at town parks.  Always clean up after your pet, and please be conscious of park-goers who may not be using the park as responsibly as you.  Leash your dog if a questionable owner/dog comes in; do not allow for an incident to take place.  ALWAYS have your eyes on your dog and be aware of their behavior; stop problems before they occur.  ALWAYS remember that you are representing your dogs, your breed, AND the NEBBC.  Your etiquette needs to indicate this.  This is the first time the NEBBC has promoted a repeating dog park event, and in order for this to continue, handlers need to 'keep it classy,' and be exemplary in controlling their dog's behavior as well as their own.  Please, no more than two dogs per handler (bring a friend if need be), and keep this very important etiquette in mind."

Here is a great excerpt from an email entailing how these particular very responsible dog owners handled their first meeting at the park:

"Better safe than sorry...   We started our meet up with just some chatter amongst owners with the dogs on leashes, letting them get acclimated to each other and such.  Brawlick is a very mild mannered pit with fairly good manners.  Sophi is a pup, with lots of energy and excitement, and then there was my Missy, which was a little hyper there, as i think she was hoping it was doggie daycare (as that's where she goes).  After spending about 10 minutes together, we walked to the play area where everyone got into the empty dog park.  We kept the dogs on leash for a little longer, so again, they could get acclimated.  I had brought some toys for the dogs to distract them with, and each dog got a squeeky ball to start working with their handlers.  

  All dogs were in great space, and interested in playing.  We then let them off leash, where the spent a better half of the next hour running and chasing the balls, ropes and sticks.    During the play time, another group of dogs joined in the park, which we introduced ourselves and our pets to.  She unfortunately let her dogs off leash quickly... but all 5 dogs got along great.  Another set of dogs came in later, and immediately started growling.  Our group grabbed our dogs to ensure there would be no issues, and that individual quickly left with her dogs who never got off leash.   I am by no means a "professional" when it comes to this stuff.  I use some common sense." This email and the way the meetup was handled are EXTREMELY appreciated.  We try not to keep these messages so long, but this is a sensitive topic, and we want this to be successful, happy and most certainly not doing any damage to our already-maligned breeds' images. THANK YOU ALL for your cooperation. This meetup is for socialized, non-aggressive dogs ONLY.  If these issues are something you need to work on, please contact me directly at justcassie101@gmail for more information.
